sain

sain — Write safe Python code like Rust 🦀

sain is a dependency-free Python library which brings the Rust ecosystem to Python, Allowing its users to write safe, idiomatic Python code just like Rust.

What sain provides

If you already know what you are looking for, the fastest way is to use the search bar,

otherwise, you may want to jump into one of these useful sections:

  • collections Implementations of the most common general purpose data structures from Rust's std::collections and friends such as HashMap, Vec.
  • Core error-handling types such as Option and Some variant, Result and Ok, Err variants.
  • The Iterator trait and its adapters.
  • Common traits such as From, Into.
  • Synchronization primitives, includes LazyLock and Once.
  • Support macros such as #[deprecated], todo!(), unimplemented!() and more.

A Tour of sain

The next section will include the most general purpose and notable features of Rust implemented in sain.

Containers and Collections

The option and result modules define optional and error-handling types, Option and Result. The iter module defines the Iterator trait.

For std::collections types, sain exposes Vec to the top level, which can be imported directly, as for the rest of the types, they all exist under sain.collections, notable ones are:

  • Vec - Built on-top of a list object, contains all of Rust's Vec methods.
  • HashMap - Built on-top of a dict object, contains all of Rust's HashMap methods.
  • Bytes and BytesMut - although these are not part of the standard library, it implements bytes::Bytes crate.

@rustc_diagnostic_item('cfg')
def cfg( target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'macos', 'unix', 'windows', 'ios']] = None, python_version: tuple[int, ...] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x86_64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> bool: 
174@rustc_diagnostic_item("cfg")
175def cfg(
176    target_os: System | None = None,
177    python_version: tuple[int, ...] | None = None,
178    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
179    impl: Python | None = None,
180) -> bool:
181    """A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns `True`.
182
183    The difference between this function and `cfg_attr` is that this function will not raise an exception.
184    Instead it will return `False` if any of the attributes fails.
185
186    Example
187    -------
188    ```py
189    import sain
190
191    if cfg(target_os="windows"):
192        print("Windows")
193    elif cfg(target_os="linux", target_arch="arm64"):
194        print("Linux")
195    else:
196        print("Something else")
197    ```
198
199    Parameters
200    ----------
201    target_os : `str | None`
202        The targeted operating system that's required for the object to be executed.
203    python_version : `tuple[int, ...] | None`
204        The targeted Python version that's required for the object to be executed. Format must be `(3, ..., ...)`
205    target_arch : `str | None`
206        The CPU targeted architecture that's required for the object to be executed.
207    impl : `str | None`
208        The Python implementation that's required for the object to be executed.
209
210    Returns
211    -------
212    `bool`
213        The condition that was checked.
214    """
215    checker = _AttrCheck(
216        lambda: None,
217        no_raise=True,
218        target_os=target_os,
219        python_version=python_version,
220        target_arch=target_arch,
221        impl=impl,
222    )
223    return checker.check_once()

A function that will run the code only if all predicate attributes returns True.

The difference between this function and cfg_attr is that this function will not raise an exception. Instead it will return False if any of the attributes fails.

Example
import sain

if cfg(target_os="windows"):
    print("Windows")
elif cfg(target_os="linux", target_arch="arm64"):
    print("Linux")
else:
    print("Something else")
Parameters
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system that's required for the object to be executed.
  • python_version (tuple[int, ...] | None): The targeted Python version that's required for the object to be executed. Format must be (3, ..., ...)
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture that's required for the object to be executed.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation that's required for the object to be executed.
Returns
  • bool: The condition that was checked.
  • # Implementations

@rustc_diagnostic_item('cfg_attr')
def cfg_attr( *, target_os: Optional[Literal['linux', 'win32', 'darwin', 'macos', 'unix', 'windows', 'ios']] = None, python_version: tuple[int, ...] | None = None, target_arch: Optional[Literal['x86', 'x86_64', 'arm', 'arm64']] = None, impl: Optional[Literal['CPython', 'PyPy', 'IronPython', 'Jython']] = None) -> Callable[[~F], ~F]: 
102@rustc_diagnostic_item("cfg_attr")
103def cfg_attr(
104    *,
105    target_os: System | None = None,
106    python_version: tuple[int, ...] | None = None,
107    target_arch: Arch | None = None,
108    impl: Python | None = None,
109) -> collections.Callable[[F], F]:
110    """Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.
111
112    If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns `False`,
113    `RuntimeError` will be raised and the object will not run.
114
115    Example
116    -------
117    ```py
118    import sain
119
120    @cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
121    def windows_only():
122        # Do stuff with Windows's API.
123        ...
124
125    # Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
126    # when creating the instance.
127    @cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
128    class Zoo:
129        @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
130        def bark(self) -> None:
131            ...
132
133    # An instance will not be created if raised.
134    zoo = Zoo()
135    # RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
136    ```
137
138    Parameters
139    ----------
140    target_os : `str | None`
141        The targeted operating system that's required for the object.
142    python_version : `tuple[int, int, int] | None`
143        The targeted Python version that's required for the object. Format must be `(3, ..., ...)`.
144    target_arch : `str | None`
145        The CPU targeted architecture that's required for the object.
146    impl : `str | None`
147        The Python implementation that's required for the object.
148
149    Raises
150    ------
151    `RuntimeError`
152        This fails if any of the attributes returns `False`.
153    `ValueError`
154        If the passed Python implementation is unknown.
155    """
156
157    def decorator(callback: F) -> F:
158        @functools.wraps(callback)
159        def wrapper(*args: typing.Any, **kwargs: typing.Any) -> F:
160            checker = _AttrCheck(
161                callback,
162                target_os=target_os,
163                python_version=python_version,
164                target_arch=target_arch,
165                impl=impl,
166            )
167            return checker(*args, **kwargs)
168
169        return typing.cast(F, wrapper)
170
171    return decorator

Conditional runtime object configuration based on passed arguments.

If the decorated object gets called and one of the attributes returns False, RuntimeError will be raised and the object will not run.

Example
import sain

@cfg_attr(target_os="windows")
def windows_only():
    # Do stuff with Windows's API.
    ...

# Mut be PyPy Python implementation or `RuntimeError` will be raised
# when creating the instance.
@cfg_attr(impl="PyPy")
class Zoo:
    @sain.cfg_attr(target_os="linux")
    def bark(self) -> None:
        ...

# An instance will not be created if raised.
zoo = Zoo()
# RuntimeError("class Zoo requires PyPy implementation")
Parameters
  • target_os (str | None): The targeted operating system that's required for the object.
  • python_version (tuple[int, int, int] | None): The targeted Python version that's required for the object. Format must be (3, ..., ...).
  • target_arch (str | None): The CPU targeted architecture that's required for the object.
  • impl (str | None): The Python implementation that's required for the object.
Raises
  • RuntimeError: This fails if any of the attributes returns False.
  • ValueError: If the passed Python implementation is unknown.

59@rustc_diagnostic_item("Default")
60@typing.runtime_checkable
61class Default(typing.Protocol[_T_co]):
62    """An interface for an object that has a default value.
63
64    Example
65    -------
66    ```py
67    from sain import Default
68
69    class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):
70
71        @staticmethod
72        def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
73            return {}
74
75    cache = Cache.default()
76    print(cache)
77    assert isinstance(cache, Default)
78    # {}
79    ```
80    """
81
82    __slots__ = ()
83
84    @rustc_diagnostic_item("default_fn")
85    @staticmethod
86    def default() -> _T_co:
87        """Return the default value of the object."""
88        raise NotImplementedError

An interface for an object that has a default value.

Example
from sain import Default

class Cache(Default[dict[str, Any]]):

    @staticmethod
    def default() -> dict[str, Any]:
        return {}

cache = Cache.default()
print(cache)
assert isinstance(cache, Default)
# {}

Implementations

This class implements Default in Rust.

Default(*args, **kwargs) 
1941def _no_init_or_replace_init(self, *args, **kwargs):
1942    cls = type(self)
1943
1944    if cls._is_protocol:
1945        raise TypeError('Protocols cannot be instantiated')
1946
1947    # Already using a custom `__init__`. No need to calculate correct
1948    # `__init__` to call. This can lead to RecursionError. See bpo-45121.
1949    if cls.__init__ is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1950        return
1951
1952    # Initially, `__init__` of a protocol subclass is set to `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1953    # The first instantiation of the subclass will call `_no_init_or_replace_init` which
1954    # searches for a proper new `__init__` in the MRO. The new `__init__`
1955    # replaces the subclass' old `__init__` (ie `_no_init_or_replace_init`). Subsequent
1956    # instantiation of the protocol subclass will thus use the new
1957    # `__init__` and no longer call `_no_init_or_replace_init`.
1958    for base in cls.__mro__:
1959        init = base.__dict__.get('__init__', _no_init_or_replace_init)
1960        if init is not _no_init_or_replace_init:
1961            cls.__init__ = init
1962            break
1963    else:
1964        # should not happen
1965        cls.__init__ = object.__init__
1966
1967    cls.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
@rustc_diagnostic_item('default_fn')

def default() -> +_T_co:

@rustc_diagnostic_item('Option')
@typing.final
class Some(typing.Generic[~T], sain.Default[ForwardRef('Option[None]')]): 
 56@rustc_diagnostic_item("Option")
 57@typing.final
 58class Some(typing.Generic[T], _default.Default["Option[None]"]):
 59    """The `Option` type represents optional value, higher-level abstraction over the `None` type.
 60
 61    It combines union of `T | None` in one convenient structure, allowing the users to manipulate and propagate
 62    the contained value idiomatically.
 63
 64    An `Option` value have multiple use cases:
 65
 66    * Initial values.
 67    * Return value for functions that may or may not contain a return value.
 68    * Optional parameters, class fields.
 69    * Swapping values.
 70
 71    Example
 72    -------
 73    ```py
 74    # the actual implementation of the object.
 75    from sain import Some
 76    # Here `Option` is used for type-hints only, you can include it under `TYPE_CHECKING` if you'd like.
 77    from sain import Option
 78
 79    def divide(numerator: float, denominator: float) -> Option[float]:
 80        if denominator == 0.0:
 81            return Some(None)
 82        return Some(numerator / denominator)
 83
 84    # Returns Option[float]
 85    result = divide(2.0, 3.0)
 86
 87    # Pattern match to retrieve the value
 88    match result:
 89        # The division is valid.
 90        case Some(x):
 91            print("Result:", x)
 92        # Invalid division, this is Some(None)
 93        case _:
 94            print("cannot divide by 0")
 95    ```
 96
 97    ### Converting `None`s into `RuntimeError`s
 98
 99    Sometimes we want to extract the value and cause an error to the caller if it doesn't exist,
100
101    because handling `Some/None` can be tedious, luckily we have several ways to deal with this.
102
103    ```py
104    def ipaddr(s: str) -> Option[tuple[int, int, int, int]]:
105        match s.split('.'):
106            case [a, b, c, d]:
107                return Some((int(a), int(b), int(c), int(d)))
108            case _:
109                return Some(None)
110
111    # calls `unwrap()` for you.
112    ip = ~ipaddr("192.168.1.19")
113    # causes a `RuntimeError` if it returns `None`.
114    ip = ipaddr("192.168.1.19").unwrap()
115    # causes a `RuntimeError` if it returns `None`, with a context message.
116    ip = ipaddr("192.168.1.19").expect("i need an ip address :<")
117    ```
118
119    The `~` operator will result in `tuple[int, int, int, int]` if the parsing succeed.
120    unless the contained value is `None`, it will cause a `RuntimeError`.
121
122    If the value must be present, use `unwrap_or`, which takes a default parameter
123    and returns it in-case `ipaddr` returns `None`
124    ```py
125    ip = ipaddr("blah blah blah").unwrap_or("192.168.1.255")
126    # Results: 192.168.1.255
127    ```
128
129    Overall, this type provides many other functional methods such as `map`, `filter`.
130
131    boolean checks such as `is_some`, `is_none`, converting between `Option` and `Result` using `ok_or`, and many more.
132    """
133
134    __slots__ = ("_value",)
135    __match_args__ = ("_value",)
136
137    def __init__(self, value: T | None, /) -> None:
138        self._value = value
139
140    @staticmethod
141    def default() -> Option[T]:
142        """Default value for `Some`. Returns `None` wrapped in `Some`.
143
144        Example
145        -------
146        ```py
147        assert Some.default() == NOTHING
148        ```
149        """
150        return NOTHING
151
152    # *- Reading the value -*
153
154    def transpose(self) -> T | None:
155        """Convert `Option[T]` into `T | None`.
156
157        Examples
158        --------
159        ```py
160        opt = Some('char')
161        x = opt.transpose()
162        assert x == 'char'
163
164        opt = Some(None)
165        assert opt.transpose() is None
166        ```
167        """
168        return self._value
169
170    def unwrap(self) -> T:
171        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or raising a `RuntimeError`.
172
173        It's usually not recommended to use this method in production code, since it raises.
174
175        Example
176        -------
177        ```py
178        value = Some(5)
179        print(value.unwrap())
180        # 5
181
182        value = Some(None)
183        print(value.unwrap())
184        # RuntimeError
185        ```
186
187        Raises
188        ------
189        `RuntimeError`
190            If the inner value is `None`.
191        """
192        if self._value is None:
193            raise RuntimeError("Called `Option.unwrap()` on `None`.") from None
194
195        return self._value
196
197    def unwrap_or(self, default: T, /) -> T:
198        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or returning `default`.
199
200        Example
201        -------
202        ```py
203        value = Some(5)
204        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
205        # 5
206
207        # Type hint is required here.
208        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
209        print(value.unwrap_or(10))
210        # 10
211        ```
212        """
213        if self._value is None:
214            return default
215
216        return self._value
217
218    def unwrap_or_else(self, f: FnOnce[T], /) -> T:
219        """Unwrap the inner value either returning if its not `None` or calling `f` to get a default value.
220
221        Example
222        -------
223        ```py
224        value = Some(5)
225        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: 10))
226        # 5
227
228        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
229        print(value.unwrap_or_else(lambda: True))
230        # True
231        ```
232        """
233        if self._value is None:
234            return f()
235
236        return self._value
237
238    @macros.unsafe
239    def unwrap_unchecked(self) -> T:
240        """Returns the contained Some value without checking that the value is not None.
241
242        Example
243        -------
244        ```py
245        v: Option[float] = Some(1.2)
246        v.unwrap_unchecked() # 1.2
247
248        v: Option[float] = Some(None)
249        print(v.unwrap_unchecked()) # Undefined Behavior
250        ```
251        """
252        #! SAFETY: The caller guarantees that the value is not None.
253        return self._value  # pyright: ignore
254
255    def expect(self, message: str, /) -> T:
256        """Returns the contained value if it is not `None` otherwise raises a `RuntimeError`.
257
258        Example
259        -------
260        ```py
261        value = Some("Hello")
262
263        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
264        # "Hello"
265
266        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
267        print(value.expect("Value is None"))
268        # RuntimeError("Value is None")
269        ```
270        """
271        if self._value is None:
272            raise RuntimeError(message)
273
274        return self._value
275
276    # *- object transformation -*
277
278    def map(self, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> Option[U]:
279        """Map the inner value to another type. Returning `Some(None)` if `T` is `None`.
280
281        Example
282        -------
283        ```py
284        value = Some(5.0)
285
286        print(value.map(lambda x: x * 2.0))
287        # Some(10.0)
288
289        value: Option[bool] = Some(None)
290        print(value)
291        # Some(None)
292        ```
293        """
294        if self._value is None:
295            return NOTHING
296
297        return Some(f(self._value))
298
299    def map_or(self, default: U, f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
300        """Map the inner value to another type or return `default` if its `None`.
301
302        Example
303        -------
304        ```py
305        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
306
307        # map to int.
308        print(value.map_or(0, int))
309        # 6
310
311        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
312        print(value.map_or(0, int)
313        # 0
314        ```
315        """
316        if self._value is None:
317            return default
318
319        return f(self._value)
320
321    def map_or_else(self, default: FnOnce[U], f: Fn[T, U], /) -> U:
322        """Map the inner value to another type, or return `default()` if its `None`.
323
324        Example
325        -------
326        ```py
327        def default() -> int:
328            return sys.getsizeof(object())
329
330        value: Option[float] = Some(5.0)
331
332        # map to int.
333        print(value.map_or_else(default, int))
334        # 6
335
336        value: Option[float] = Some(None)
337        print(value.map_or_else(default, int)
338        # 28 <- size of object()
339        ```
340        """
341        if self._value is None:
342            return default()
343
344        return f(self._value)
345
346    def filter(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> Option[T]:
347        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`,
348
349        otherwise calls the predicate and returns `Some(T)` if the predicate returns `True`.
350
351        Example
352        -------
353        ```py
354        value = Some([1, 2, 3])
355
356        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 in x))
357        # Some([1, 2, 3])
358
359        value: Option[int] = Some([1, 2, 3]) # or Some(None)
360        print(value.filter(lambda x: 1 not in x))
361        # None
362        ```
363        """
364        if (value := self._value) is not None:
365            if predicate(value):
366                return Some(value)
367
368        return NOTHING
369
370    def ok_or(self, err: U) -> _result.Result[T, U]:
371        """Transforms the `Option<T>` into a `Result<T, E>`, mapping `Some(v)` to `Ok(v)` and `None` to `Err(err)`.
372
373        Example
374        -------
375        ```py
376        xyz: Option[str] = Some("foo")
377        assert xyz.ok_or(None) == Ok("foo")
378
379        xyz: Option[str] = Some(None)
380        assert xyz.ok_or(None) == Err(None)
381        ```
382        """
383        if self._value is None:
384            return _result.Err(err)
385
386        return _result.Ok(self._value)
387
388    def ok_or_else(self, err: FnOnce[U]) -> _result.Result[T, U]:
389        """Transforms the `Option<T>` into a `Result<T, E>`, mapping `Some(v)` to `Ok(v)` and `None` to `Err(err())`.
390
391        Example
392        -------
393        ```py
394        xyz: Option[str] = Some("foo")
395        assert xyz.ok_or(None) == Ok("foo")
396
397        xyz: Option[str] = Some(None)
398        assert xyz.ok_or(None) == Err(None)
399        ```
400        """
401        if self._value is None:
402            return _result.Err(err())
403
404        return _result.Ok(self._value)
405
406    def zip(self, other: Option[U]) -> Option[tuple[T, U]]:
407        """Zips `self` with `other`.
408
409        if `self` is `Some(s)` and other is `Some(o)`, this returns `Some((s, o))` otherwise `None`.
410
411        Example
412        -------
413        ```py
414        x = Some(1)
415        y = Some("hi")
416        z: Option[str] = Some(None)
417
418        assert x.zip(y) == Some((1, "hi"))
419        assert x.zip(z) == Some(None)
420        ```
421        """
422        if self._value is not None and other._value is not None:
423            return Some((self._value, other._value))
424
425        return NOTHING
426
427    def zip_with(
428        self, other: Option[U], f: collections.Callable[[T, U], T_co]
429    ) -> Option[T_co]:
430        """Zips `self` with `other` using function `f`.
431
432        if `self` is `Some(s)` and other is `Some(o)`, this returns `Some(f(s, o))` otherwise `None`.
433
434        Example
435        -------
436        ```py
437        @dataclass
438        class Point:
439            x: float
440            y: float
441
442        x, y = Some(32.1), Some(42.4)
443        assert x.zip_with(y, Point) == Some(Point(32.1, 42.4))
444        ```
445        """
446        if self._value is not None and other._value is not None:
447            return Some(f(self._value, other._value))
448
449        return NOTHING
450
451    # *- Inner operations *-
452
453    def take(self) -> Option[T]:
454        """Take the value from `self` Setting it to `None`, and then return `Some(v)`.
455
456        If you don't care about the original value, use `Option.clear()` instead.
457
458        Example
459        -------
460        ```py
461        original = Some("Hi")
462        new = original.take()
463
464        print(original, new)
465        # None, Some("Hi")
466        ```
467        """
468        if self._value is None:
469            return NOTHING
470
471        val = self._value
472        self._value = None
473        return Some(val)
474
475    def take_if(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[T], bool]) -> Option[T]:
476        """Take the value from `Self`, Setting it to `None` only if predicate returns `True`.
477
478        If you don't care about the original value, use `Option.clear_if()` instead.
479
480        Example
481        -------
482        ```py
483        def validate(email: str) -> bool:
484            # you can obviously validate this better.
485            return email.find('@') == 1
486
487        original = Some("flex@gg.com")
488        valid = original.take_if(validate)
489        assert is_allowed.is_some() and original.is_none()
490
491        original = Some("mail.example.com")
492        invalid = original.take_if(validate)
493        assert invalid.is_none() and original.is_some()
494        ```
495        """
496        if self.map_or(False, predicate):
497            return self.take()
498
499        return NOTHING
500
501    def clear(self) -> None:
502        """Clear the inner value, setting it to `None`.
503
504        If you care about the original value, use `Option.take()` instead.
505
506        Example
507        -------
508        ```py
509        value = Some("Hello")
510        value.clear()
511        assert value.is_none()
512        ```
513        """
514        self._value = None
515
516    def clear_if(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> None:
517        """Clear the inner value, setting it to `None` if the predicate returns `True`.
518
519        If you care about the original value, use `Option.take_if()` instead.
520
521        Example
522        -------
523        ```py
524        value = Some("Hello")
525        value.clear_if(lambda x: x == "Hello")
526        assert value.is_none()
527        ```
528        """
529        if self._value is not None and predicate(self._value):
530            self._value = None
531
532    def replace(self, value: T) -> Option[T]:
533        """Replace the contained value with another value.
534
535        Use `Option.insert` if you want to return the original value
536        that got inserted instead of `self`
537
538        Example
539        -------
540        ```py
541        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
542        value.replace("Hello")
543        # Some("Hello")
544        ```
545        """
546        self._value = value
547        return self
548
549    def insert(self, value: T) -> T:
550        """Insert a value into the option, and then return a reference to it.
551
552        This will overwrite the old value if it was already contained.
553
554        Example
555        -------
556        ```py
557        flag: Option[bool] = Some(None)
558        flag_ref = flag.insert(True)
559        assert flag_ref == True
560        assert flag.unwrap() == True
561        ```
562        """
563        self._value = value
564        return value
565
566    def get_or_insert(self, value: T) -> T:
567        """Insert a value into the option if it was `None`,
568        and then return a reference to it.
569
570        Example
571        -------
572        ```py
573        state: Option[bool] = Some(None)
574        assert state.get_or_insert(True) is True
575        assert state.get_or_insert(False) is True
576        ```
577        """
578        if self._value is not None:
579            return self._value
580
581        self._value = value
582        return value
583
584    def get_or_insert_with(self, f: FnOnce[T]) -> T:
585        """Insert a value into the option computed from `f()` if it was `None`,
586        and then return a reference to it.
587
588        Example
589        -------
590        ```py
591        flag: Option[bool] = Some(None)
592        flag_ref = flag.insert(True)
593        assert flag_ref == True
594        assert flag.unwrap() == True
595        ```
596        """
597        if self._value is not None:
598            return self._value
599
600        v = self._value = f()
601        return v
602
603    def and_ok(self, optb: Option[T]) -> Option[T]:
604        """Returns `None` if `self` or `optb` is `None`, otherwise return `optb`.
605
606        aliases: `Option::and`
607
608        Example
609        -------
610        ```py
611        x = Some(1)
612        y: Option[str] = Some(None)
613        assert x.and_ok(y) == Some(None)
614
615        x: Option[str] = Some(None)
616        y = Some(1)
617        assert x.and_ok(y) == Some(None)
618
619        y: Option[str] = Some("hi")
620        y = Some(100)
621        assert x.and_ok(y) == Some(100)
622        ```
623        """
624        if self._value is None or optb._value is None:
625            return optb
626
627        return NOTHING
628
629    def and_then(self, f: Fn[T, Option[T]]) -> Option[T]:
630        """Returns `Some(None)` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise call `f()`
631        on `T` and return `Option[T]`.
632
633        Example
634        -------
635        ```py
636        value = Some(5)
637        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(x * 2)))
638        # Some(10)
639
640        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
641        print(value.and_then(lambda x: Some(x * 2)))
642        # Some(None)
643        ```
644        """
645        if self._value is None:
646            return NOTHING
647
648        return f(self._value)
649
650    def inspect(self, f: Fn[T, typing.Any]) -> Option[T]:
651        """Calls `f()` on the contained value if it was `Some(v)`, otherwise does nothing.
652
653        Example
654        -------
655        ```py
656        def debug(x: str) -> None:
657            print("Debugging:", x)
658
659        value = Some("foo")
660        inner = value.inspect(debug).expect("no value to debug")
661        # prints: Debugging: "foo"
662
663        value: Option[str] = Some(None)
664        value.inspect(debug) # prints nothing
665        """
666        if self._value is not None:
667            f(self._value)
668
669        return self
670
671    # *- Builder methods *-
672
673    def iter(self) -> _iter.Iterator[T]:
674        """Returns an iterator over the contained value.
675
676        Example
677        -------
678        ```py
679        from sain import Some
680        value = Some("gg").iter()
681        assert value.next() == Some("gg")
682
683        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
684        assert value.iter().next().is_none()
685        ```
686        """
687        if self._value is None:
688            return _iter.empty()
689
690        return _iter.once(self._value)
691
692    # *- Boolean checks *-
693
694    def is_some(self) -> bool:
695        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
696
697        Example
698        -------
699        ```py
700        value = Some(5)
701        print(value.is_some())
702        # True
703
704        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
705        print(value.is_some())
706        # False
707        ```
708        """
709        return self._value is not None
710
711    def is_some_and(self, predicate: Fn[T, bool]) -> bool:
712        """Returns `True` if the contained value is not `None` and
713        the predicate returns `True`, otherwise returns `False`.
714
715        Example
716        -------
717        ```py
718        value = Some(5)
719        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
720        # True
721
722        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
723        print(value.is_some_and(lambda x: x > 3))
724        # False
725        ```
726        """
727        return self._value is not None and predicate(self._value)
728
729    def is_none(self) -> bool:
730        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `None`, otherwise returns `False`.
731
732        Example
733        -------
734        ```py
735        value = Some(5)
736        print(value.is_none())
737        # False
738
739        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
740        print(value.is_none())
741        # True
742        ```
743        """
744        return self._value is None
745
746    def is_none_or(self, f: Fn[T, bool]) -> bool:
747        """Returns `True` if the contained value is `None` or the predicate returns `True`,
748        otherwise returns `False`.
749
750        Example
751        -------
752        ```py
753        value = Some(5)
754        print(value.is_none_or(lambda x: x > 3))
755        # False
756
757        value: Option[int] = Some(None)
758        print(value.is_none_or(lambda x: x > 3))
759        # True
760        ```
761        """
762        match self._value:
763            case None:
764                return True
765            case x:
766                return f(x)
767
768    def __repr__(self) -> str:
769        if self._value is None:
770            return "None"
771        return f"Some({self._value!r})"
772
773    __str__ = __repr__
774
775    def __invert__(self) -> T:
776        return self.unwrap()
777
778    def __or__(self, other: T) -> T:
779        return self.unwrap_or(other)
780
781    def __bool__(self) -> bool:
782        return self.is_some()
783
784    def __eq__(self, other: None | object) -> bool:
785        if other is None:
786            return self._value is None
787
788        if not isinstance(other, Some):
789            return NotImplemented
790
791        return self._value == other._value  # pyright: ignore[reportUnknownVariableType, reportUnknownMemberType]
792
793    def __ne__(self, other: object) -> bool:
794        return not self.__eq__(other)
795
796    def __hash__(self) -> int:
797        return hash(self._value)

The Option type represents optional value, higher-level abstraction over the None type.

It combines union of T | None in one convenient structure, allowing the users to manipulate and propagate the contained value idiomatically.

An Option value have multiple use cases:

  • Initial values.
  • Return value for functions that may or may not contain a return value.
  • Optional parameters, class fields.
  • Swapping values.
Example
# the actual implementation of the object.
from sain import Some
# Here `Option` is used for type-hints only, you can include it under `TYPE_CHECKING` if you'd like.
from sain import Option

def divide(numerator: float, denominator: float) -> Option[float]:
    if denominator == 0.0:
        return Some(None)
    return Some(numerator / denominator)

# Returns Option[float]
result = divide(2.0, 3.0)

# Pattern match to retrieve the value
match result:
    # The division is valid.
    case Some(x):
        print("Result:", x)
    # Invalid division, this is Some(None)
    case _:
        print("cannot divide by 0")

Converting Nones into RuntimeErrors

Sometimes we want to extract the value and cause an error to the caller if it doesn't exist,

because handling Some/None can be tedious, luckily we have several ways to deal with this.

def ipaddr(s: str) -> Option[tuple[int, int, int, int]]:
    match s.split('.'):
        case [a, b, c, d]:
            return Some((int(a), int(b), int(c), int(d)))
        case _:
            return Some(None)

# calls `unwrap()` for you.
ip = ~ipaddr("192.168.1.19")
# causes a `RuntimeError` if it returns `None`.
ip = ipaddr("192.168.1.19").unwrap()
# causes a `RuntimeError` if it returns `None`, with a context message.
ip = ipaddr("192.168.1.19").expect("i need an ip address :<")

The ~ operator will result in tuple[int, int, int, int] if the parsing succeed. unless the contained value is None, it will cause a RuntimeError.

If the value must be present, use unwrap_or, which takes a default parameter and returns it in-case ipaddr returns None

ip = ipaddr("blah blah blah").unwrap_or("192.168.1.255")
# Results: 192.168.1.255

Overall, this type provides many other functional methods such as map, filter.

boolean checks such as is_some, is_none, converting between Option and Result using ok_or, and many more.

279        """Map the inner value to another type. Returning `Some(None)` if `T` is `None`.

class Iter(typing.Generic[~Item], sain.Iterator[~Item]): 
 999@rustc_diagnostic_item("Iter")
1000@typing.final
1001@diagnostic
1002class Iter(typing.Generic[Item], Iterator[Item]):
1003    """a lazy iterator that has its items ready in-memory.
1004
1005    This is similar to Rust `std::slice::Iter<T>` item which iterables can build
1006    from this via `.iter()` method.
1007
1008    Example
1009    -------
1010    ```py
1011    iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
1012
1013    # Limit the results to 2.
1014    for item in iterator.take(2):
1015        print(item)
1016    # 1
1017    # 2
1018
1019    # Filter the results.
1020    for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
1021        print(item)
1022    # 2
1023    # 3
1024    # 3
1025
1026    # Indexing is supported.
1027    print(iterator[0])
1028    # 1
1029    ```
1030
1031    Parameters
1032    ----------
1033    items: `Iterable[Item]`
1034        The items to iterate over. This can be anything that implements `__iter__` and `__next__`.
1035    """
1036
1037    __slots__ = ("_it",)
1038
1039    def __init__(self, iterable: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> None:
1040        self._it = iter(iterable)
1041
1042    def clone(self) -> Iter[Item]:
1043        """Return a copy of this iterator.
1044
1045        ```py
1046        it = Iterator([1, 2, 3])
1047
1048        for i in it.clone():
1049            ...
1050
1051        # The actual iterator hasn't been exhausted.
1052        assert it.count() == 3
1053        ```
1054        """
1055        return Iter(copy.copy(self._it))
1056
1057    def __next__(self) -> Item:
1058        return next(self._it)
1059
1060    def __getitem__(self, index: int) -> Item:
1061        return self.skip(index).first().unwrap_or_else(oob)
1062
1063    def __contains__(self, item: Item) -> bool:
1064        return item in self._it

a lazy iterator that has its items ready in-memory.

This is similar to Rust std::slice::Iter<T> item which iterables can build from this via sain.iter method.

Example
iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])

# Limit the results to 2.
for item in iterator.take(2):
    print(item)
# 1
# 2

# Filter the results.
for item in iterator.filter(lambda item: item > 1):
    print(item)
# 2
# 3
# 3

# Indexing is supported.
print(iterator[0])
# 1
Parameters
  • items (Iterable[Item]): The items to iterate over. This can be anything that implements __iter__ and __next__.

@rustc_diagnostic_item('Iterator')
class Iterator(typing.Generic[~Item], abc.ABC, sain.Default[ForwardRef('Empty[Item]')]): 
124@rustc_diagnostic_item("Iterator")
125class Iterator(
126    typing.Generic[Item],
127    abc.ABC,
128    _default.Default["Empty[Item]"],
129):
130    """An abstract interface for dealing with iterators.
131
132    This is exactly the same trait as `core::iter::Iterator` trait from Rust.
133
134    This is the main interface that any type can implement by basically inheriting from it.
135    The method `__next__` is the only method that needs to be implemented, You get all the other methods for free.
136
137    If you want to use a ready iterator for general purposes, Use `Iter`. This interface is only for implementers
138    and type hints.
139
140    Example
141    -------
142    ```py
143    @dataclass
144    class Counter(Iterator[int]):
145        start: int = 0
146        stop: int | None = None
147
148        # implement the required method.
149        def __next__(self) -> int:
150            result = self.start
151            self.start += 1
152
153            if self.stop is not None and result >= self.stop:
154                raise StopIteration
155
156            return result
157
158    counter = Counter(start=0, stop=10)
159    for i in counter.map(lambda x: x * 2): # multiply each number
160        ...
161    ```
162    """
163
164    __slots__ = ()
165
166    @abc.abstractmethod
167    def __next__(self) -> Item:
168        raise NotImplementedError
169

171    # const functions #
172    ###################

174    @staticmethod
175    @typing.final
176    def default() -> Empty[Item]:
177        """Return the default iterator for this type. It returns an empty iterator.
178
179        Example
180        -------
181        ```py
182        it: Iterator[int] = Iter.default()
183        assert t.next().is_none()
184        ```
185        """
186        return Empty()
187
188    @typing.overload
189    def collect(self) -> collections.MutableSequence[Item]: ...
190
191    @typing.overload
192    def collect(
193        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]
194    ) -> collections.MutableSequence[OtherItem]: ...
195
196    @typing.final
197    def collect(
198        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem] | None = None
199    ) -> collections.MutableSequence[Item] | collections.MutableSequence[OtherItem]:
200        """Collects all items in the iterator into a sequence.
201
202        Example
203        -------
204        ```py
205        iterator = Iter(range(3))
206        iterator.collect()
207        # (0, 1, 2, 3)
208        iterator.collect(cast=str) # Map each element and collect it.
209        # ('0', '1', '2', '3')
210        ```
211
212        Parameters
213        ----------
214        cast: `T | None`
215            An optional type to cast the items into.
216            If not provided the items will be returned as it's original type.
217        """
218        if cast is not None:
219            return list(cast(i) for i in self)
220
221        return list(_ for _ in self)
222
223    @typing.final
224    def collect_into(self, collection: Collector[Item]) -> None:
225        """Consume this iterator, extending all items in the iterator into a mutable `collection`.
226
227        Example
228        -------
229        ```py
230        iterator = Iter([1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 2, 6])
231        uniques = set()
232        iterator.collect_into(uniques)
233        # assert uniques == {1, 2, 3, 4, 6}
234        ```
235
236        Parameters
237        ----------
238        collection: `MutableSequence[T]` | `set[T]`
239            The collection to extend the items in this iterator with.
240        """
241        if isinstance(collection, collections.MutableSequence):
242            collection.extend(_ for _ in self)
243        elif isinstance(collection, collections.MutableSet):
244            collection.update(_ for _ in self)
245        else:
246            for idx, item in enumerate(self):
247                collection[idx] = item
248
249    @typing.final
250    def to_vec(self) -> _vec.Vec[Item]:
251        """Convert this iterator into `Vec[T]`.
252
253        Example
254        -------
255        ```py
256        it = sain.iter.once(0)
257        vc = it.to_vec()
258
259        assert to_vec == [0]
260        ```
261        """
262        return _vec.Vec(_ for _ in self)
263
264    @typing.final
265    def sink(self) -> None:
266        """Consume all elements from this iterator, flushing it into the sink.
267
268        Example
269        -------
270        ```py
271        it = Iter((1, 2, 3))
272        it.sink()
273        assert it.next().is_none()
274        ```
275        """
276        for _ in self:
277            pass

279    @typing.final
280    def raw_parts(self) -> collections.Generator[Item, None, None]:
281        """Decompose this iterator into a `Generator[Item]` that yields all of the remaining items.
282
283        This mainly used for objects that needs to satisfy its exact type.
284
285        ```py
286        it = Iter("cba")
287        sort = sorted(it.raw_parts())
288
289        assert it.count() == 0
290        assert sort == ["a", "b", "c"]
291        ```
292        """
293        for item in self:
294            yield item

300    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
301        """Advance the iterator, Returning the next item, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
302
303        Example
304        -------
305        ```py
306        iterator = Iter(["1", "2"])
307        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
308        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
309        assert iterator.next().is_none()
310        ```
311        """
312        try:
313            return _option.Some(self.__next__())
314        except StopIteration:
315            # ! SAFETY: No more items in the iterator.
316            return _option.NOTHING
317
318    def cloned(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
319        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
320
321        If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements.
322        use `Iter.clone()`
323
324        .. note::
325            This method calls [`copy.copy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
326            on each item that is being yielded.
327
328        Example
329        -------
330        ```py
331        @dataclass
332        class User:
333            users_ids: list[int] = []
334
335        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
336        user = User()
337        it = Iter((user, user))
338
339        for u in it.cloned():
340            u.user_ids.append(1)
341
342        # We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
343        # since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
344        assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
345        ```
346        """
347        return Cloned(self)
348
349    def copied(self) -> Copied[Item]:
350        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
351
352        If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `.cloned()` instead.
353
354        .. note::
355            This method simply calls [`copy.deepcopy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
356            on each item that is being yielded.
357
358        Example
359        -------
360        ```py
361        @dataclass
362        class User:
363            users_ids: list[int] = []
364
365        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
366        user = User()
367        it = Iter((user, user))
368
369        for u in it.copied():
370            # A new list is created for each item.
371            u.user_ids.append(1)
372
373        # The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
374        assert len(user.user_ids) == 0
375        ```
376        """
377        return Copied(self)
378
379    def map(self, fn: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem]) -> Map[Item, OtherItem]:
380        """Maps each item in the iterator to another type.
381
382        Example
383        -------
384        ```py
385        iterator = Iter(["1", "2", "3"]).map(int)
386
387        for item in iterator:
388            assert isinstance(item, int)
389        ```
390
391        Parameters
392        ----------
393        predicate: `Callable[[Item], OtherItem]`
394            The function to map each item in the iterator to the other type.
395        """
396        return Map(self, fn)

415        """Take the first number of items until the number of items

418        Example

447    def enumerate(self, *, start: int = 0) -> Enumerate[Item]:
448        """Create a new iterator that yields a tuple of the index and item.

464    def take_while(self, f: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> TakeWhile[Item]:
465        """yields items from the iterator while predicate returns `True`.
466
467        The rest of the items are discarded as soon as the predicate returns `False`
468
469        Example
470        -------
471        ```py
472        iterator = Iter(['a', 'ab', 'xd', 'ba'])
473        for x in iterator.take_while(lambda x: 'a' in x):
474            print(x)
475
476        # a
477        # ab
478        ```
479
480        Parameters
481        ----------
482        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
483            The function to predicate each item in the iterator.
484        """
485        return TakeWhile(self, f)

508    def chunks(self, chunk_size: int, /) -> Chunks[Item]:
509        """Returns an iterator over `chunk_size` elements of the iterator at a time,
510        starting at the beginning of the iterator.
511
512        Example
513        -------
514        ```py
515        iter = Iter(['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'])
516        chunks = iter.chunks()
517        assert chunks.next().unwrap() == ['a', 'b']

525    def all(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
526        """Return `True` if all items in the iterator match the predicate.
527
528        Example
529        -------
530        ```py
531        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
532        while iterator.all(lambda item: isinstance(item, int)):
533            print("Still all integers")
534            continue
535            # Still all integers
536        ```
537
538        Parameters
539        ----------
540        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
541            The function to test each item in the iterator.
542        """
543        return all(predicate(item) for item in self)

545    def any(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> bool:
546        """`True` if any items in the iterator match the predicate.
547
548        Example
549        -------
550        ```py
551        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
552        if iterator.any(lambda item: isinstance(item, int)):
553            print("At least one item is an int.")
554        # At least one item is an int.
555        ```
556
557        Parameters
558        ----------
559        predicate: `collections.Callable[[Item], bool]`
560            The function to test each item in the iterator.
561        """
562        return any(predicate(item) for item in self)

564    def zip(
565        self, other: collections.Iterable[OtherItem]
566    ) -> Iter[tuple[Item, OtherItem]]:
567        """Zips the iterator with another iterable.
568
569        Example
570        -------
571        ```py
572        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
573        for item, other_item in iterator.zip([4, 5, 6]):

584        -------

586            The zipped iterator.

588        """

591    def sort(
592        self,
593        *,

595        reverse: bool = False,

598

620    def reversed(self) -> Iter[Item]:
621        """Returns a new iterator that yields the items in the iterator in reverse order.
622
623        This consumes this iterator into a sequence and return a new iterator containing all of the elements
624        in reversed order.
625
626        Example
627        -------
628        ```py
629        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
630        for item in iterator.reversed():
631            print(item)
632        # 7
633        # 6
634        # 1
635        # 3
636        ```
637        """
638        # NOTE: In order to reverse the iterator we need to
639        # first collect it into some collection.
640        return Iter(reversed(list(_ for _ in self)))

642    def union(self, other: collections.Iterable[Item]) -> Iter[Item]:
643        """Returns a new iterator that yields all items from both iterators.

668    def first(self) -> Option[Item]:
669        """Returns the first item in the iterator.
670
671        Example

674        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
675        iterator.first().is_some_and(lambda x: x == 3)
676        ```

678        return self.take(1).next()

680    def last(self) -> Option[Item]:
681        """Returns the last item in the iterator.
682
683        Example

686        iterator = Iter([3, 1, 6, 7])
687        iterator.last().is_some_and(lambda x: x == 7)
688        ```
689        """

692    def count(self) -> int:
693        """Return the count of elements in memory this iterator has.
694
695        Example
696        -------
697        ```py
698        it = Iter(range(3))
699        assert it.count() == 3
700        ```
701        """
702        count = 0
703        for _ in self:
704            count += 1
705
706        return count

708    def find(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Option[Item]:
709        """Searches for an element of an iterator that satisfies a predicate.
710
711        If you want the position of the element, use `Iterator.position` instead.
712
713        `find()` takes a lambda that returns true or false. It applies this closure to each element of the iterator,
714        and if any of them return true, then find() returns `Some(element)`. If they all return false, it returns None.
715
716        Example
717        -------
718        ```py
719        it = Iter(range(10))
720        item = it.find(lambda num: num > 5)
721        print(item) # 6
722        ```
723        """
724        for item in self:
725            if predicate(item):
726                return _option.Some(item)
727
728        # no more items
729        return _option.NOTHING
730
731    def position(self, predicate: collections.Callable[[Item], bool]) -> Option[int]:
732        """Searches for the position of an element in the iterator that satisfies a predicate.
733
734        If you want the object itself, use `Iterator.find` instead.
735
736        `position()` takes a lambda that returns true or false. It applies this closure to each element of the iterator,
737        and if any of them return true, then position() returns `Some(position_of_element)`. If they all return false, it returns None.
738
739        Example
740        -------
741        ```py
742        it = Iter(range(10))
743        position = it.find(lambda num: num > 5)
744        assert position.unwrap() == 6
745        ```
746        """
747        for position, value in self.enumerate():
748            if predicate(value):
749                return _option.Some(position)
750
751        # no more items
752        return _option.NOTHING
753
754    def fold(
755        self, init: OtherItem, f: collections.Callable[[OtherItem, Item], OtherItem]
756    ) -> OtherItem:
757        """Folds every element into an accumulator by applying an operation, returning the final result.
758
759        fold() takes two arguments: an initial value, and a closure with two arguments: an ‘accumulator’, and an element.
760        The closure returns the value that the accumulator should have for the next iteration.
761
762        The initial value is the value the accumulator will have on the first call.
763
764        After applying this closure to every element of the iterator, fold() returns the accumulator.
765
766        This operation is sometimes called ‘reduce’ or ‘inject’.
767
768        Example
769        -------
770        ```py
771        a = Iter([1, 2, 3, 4])
772        sum = a.fold(0, lambda acc, elem: acc + elem)
773        assert sum == 10
774        ```
775        """
776        accum = init
777        while True:
778            try:
779                x = self.__next__()
780                accum = f(accum, x)
781            except StopIteration:
782                break
783
784        return accum
785
786    def advance_by(self, n: int) -> _result.Result[None, int]:
787        """Advances the iterator by `n` elements.
788
789        Returns `Result[None, int]`, where `Ok(None)` means the iterator
790        advanced successfully, and `Err(int)` if `None` encountered, where `int`
791        represents the remaining number of steps that could not be advanced because the iterator ran out.
792
793        Example
794        -------
795        ```py
796        it = into_iter([1, 2, 3, 4])
797        assert it.advance_by(2).is_ok()
798        assert it.next() == Some(3)
799        assert it.advance_by(0).is_ok()
800        assert it.advance_by(100) == Err(99)
801        ```
802        """
803        for i in range(n):
804            try:
805                self.__next__()
806            except StopIteration:
807                return _result.Err(n - i)
808
809        return _result.Ok(None)
810
811    def nth(self, n: int) -> Option[Item]:
812        """Returns the `n`th element of the iterator
813
814        Just like normal indexing, the count `n` starts from zero, so `nth(0)` returns the first
815        value.
816
817        Note all elements before `n` will be skipped / consumed.
818
819        Example
820        -------
821        ```py
822        a = into_iter([1, 2, 3])
823        assert a.iter().nth(1) == Some(2)
824        ```
825        """
826        for _ in range(n):
827            try:
828                self.__next__()
829            except StopIteration:
830                return _option.NOTHING
831
832        return self.next()
833
834    def sum(self: Sum) -> int:
835        """Sums an iterator of a possible type `T` that can be converted to an integer.
836
837        where `T` is a typeof (`int`, `float`, `str`, `ReadableBuffer`, `SupportsTrunc`, `SupportsIndex`).
838
839        Example
840        -------
841        ```py
842        numbers: Iterator[str] = Iter(["1", "2", "3"])
843        total = numbers.sum()
844        assert total == 6
845        ```
846        """
847        return sum(int(_) for _ in self)

849    def for_each(self, func: collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]) -> None:
850        """Calls `func` on each item in the iterator.
851
852        Example
853        -------
854        ```py
855        iterator = Iter([1, 2, 3])
856        iterator.for_each(lambda item: print(item))
857        # 1
858        # 2
859        # 3
860        ```
861
862        Parameters
863        ----------
864        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], typing.Any]`
865            The function to call on each item in the iterator.
866        """
867        for item in self:
868            func(item)
869
870    async def async_for_each(
871        self,
872        func: collections.Callable[
873            [Item], collections.Coroutine[typing.Any, typing.Any, OtherItem]
874        ],
875    ) -> _result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], futures.JoinError]:
876        """Calls the async function on each item in the iterator *concurrently*.
877
878        Concurrently meaning that the next item will not wait for other items
879        to finish to execute, each item gets called in a separate task.
880
881        After all the tasks finish, a `Result[list[T], JoinError]` will be returned,
882        which will need to be handled by the caller.
883
884        Example
885        -------
886        ```py
887        async def create_user(username: str) -> None:
888            await aiohttp.request("POST", f'.../{username}')
889
890        async def main():
891            users = sain.into_iter(["Danny", "Flower"])
892            match await users.async_for_each(lambda username: create_user(username)):
893                case Ok(result):
894                    # all good
895                case Err(why):
896                    print(f"couldn't gather all futures, err={why}")
897        ```
898
899        Parameters
900        ----------
901        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], Coroutine[None, Any, Any]]`
902            The async function to call on each item in the iterator.
903        """
904        return await futures.join(*(func(item) for item in self))
905
906    def __reversed__(self) -> Iter[Item]:
907        return self.reversed()
908
909    def __repr__(self) -> str:
910        return "<Iterator>"
911
912    def __copy__(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
913        return self.cloned()
914
915    def __deepcopy__(
916        self, memo: collections.MutableMapping[int, typing.Any], /
917    ) -> Copied[Item]:
918        return self.copied()
919
920    def __len__(self) -> int:
921        return self.count()
922
923    def __iter__(self) -> Iterator[Item]:
924        return self

An abstract interface for dealing with iterators.

This is exactly the same trait as core::iter::Iterator trait from Rust.

This is the main interface that any type can implement by basically inheriting from it. The method __next__ is the only method that needs to be implemented, You get all the other methods for free.

If you want to use a ready iterator for general purposes, Use Iter. This interface is only for implementers and type hints.

Example
@dataclass
class Counter(Iterator[int]):
    start: int = 0
    stop: int | None = None

    # implement the required method.
    def __next__(self) -> int:
        result = self.start
        self.start += 1

        if self.stop is not None and result >= self.stop:
            raise StopIteration

        return result

counter = Counter(start=0, stop=10)
for i in counter.map(lambda x: x * 2): # multiply each number
    ...

Implementations

This class implements Iterator in Rust.

198        self, *, cast: collections.Callable[[Item], OtherItem] | None = None

def collect_into(self, collection: 'Collector[Item]') -> None: 
223    @typing.final
224    def collect_into(self, collection: Collector[Item]) -> None:
225        """Consume this iterator, extending all items in the iterator into a mutable `collection`.
226
227        Example
228        -------
229        ```py
230        iterator = Iter([1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 2, 6])
231        uniques = set()
232        iterator.collect_into(uniques)
233        # assert uniques == {1, 2, 3, 4, 6}
234        ```
235
236        Parameters
237        ----------
238        collection: `MutableSequence[T]` | `set[T]`
239            The collection to extend the items in this iterator with.
240        """
241        if isinstance(collection, collections.MutableSequence):
242            collection.extend(_ for _ in self)
243        elif isinstance(collection, collections.MutableSet):
244            collection.update(_ for _ in self)
245        else:
246            for idx, item in enumerate(self):
247                collection[idx] = item

def next(self) -> 'Option[Item]': 
300    def next(self) -> Option[Item]:
301        """Advance the iterator, Returning the next item, `Some(None)` if all items yielded.
302
303        Example
304        -------
305        ```py
306        iterator = Iter(["1", "2"])
307        assert iterator.next() == Some("1")
308        assert iterator.next() == Some("2")
309        assert iterator.next().is_none()
310        ```
311        """
312        try:
313            return _option.Some(self.__next__())
314        except StopIteration:
315            # ! SAFETY: No more items in the iterator.
316            return _option.NOTHING

def cloned(self) -> sain.iter.Cloned[~Item]: 
318    def cloned(self) -> Cloned[Item]:
319        """Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.
320
321        If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements.
322        use `Iter.clone()`
323
324        .. note::
325            This method calls [`copy.copy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
326            on each item that is being yielded.
327
328        Example
329        -------
330        ```py
331        @dataclass
332        class User:
333            users_ids: list[int] = []
334
335        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
336        user = User()
337        it = Iter((user, user))
338
339        for u in it.cloned():
340            u.user_ids.append(1)
341
342        # We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
343        # since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
344        assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
345        ```
346        """
347        return Cloned(self)

Creates an iterator which shallow copies its elements by reference.

If you need a copy of the actual iterator and not the elements. use Iter.clone()

This method calls copy.copy() on each item that is being yielded.

Example
@dataclass
class User:
    users_ids: list[int] = []

# An iterator which elements points to the same user.
user = User()
it = Iter((user, user))

for u in it.cloned():
    u.user_ids.append(1)

# We iterated over the same user pointer twice and appended "1"
# since `copy` returns a shallow copy of nested structures.
assert len(user.user_ids) == 2
def copied(self) -> sain.iter.Copied[~Item]: 
349    def copied(self) -> Copied[Item]:
350        """Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.
351
352        If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use `.cloned()` instead.
353
354        .. note::
355            This method simply calls [`copy.deepcopy()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/copy.html)
356            on each item that is being yielded.
357
358        Example
359        -------
360        ```py
361        @dataclass
362        class User:
363            users_ids: list[int] = []
364
365        # An iterator which elements points to the same user.
366        user = User()
367        it = Iter((user, user))
368
369        for u in it.copied():
370            # A new list is created for each item.
371            u.user_ids.append(1)
372
373        # The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
374        assert len(user.user_ids) == 0
375        ```
376        """
377        return Copied(self)

Creates an iterator which copies all of its elements by value.

If you only need a copy of the item reference, Use .cloned() instead.

This method simply calls copy.deepcopy() on each item that is being yielded.

Example

    users_ids: list[int] = []

# An iterator which elements points to the same user.

it = Iter((user, user))

for u in it.copied():
    # A new list is created for each item.
    u.user_ids.append(1)

# The actual list is untouched since we consumed a deep copy of it.
assert len(user.user_ids) == 0

def fold( self, init: ~OtherItem, f: Callable[[~OtherItem, ~Item], ~OtherItem]) -> ~OtherItem: 
754    def fold(
755        self, init: OtherItem, f: collections.Callable[[OtherItem, Item], OtherItem]
756    ) -> OtherItem:
757        """Folds every element into an accumulator by applying an operation, returning the final result.
758
759        fold() takes two arguments: an initial value, and a closure with two arguments: an ‘accumulator’, and an element.
760        The closure returns the value that the accumulator should have for the next iteration.
761
762        The initial value is the value the accumulator will have on the first call.
763
764        After applying this closure to every element of the iterator, fold() returns the accumulator.
765
766        This operation is sometimes called ‘reduce’ or ‘inject’.
767
768        Example
769        -------
770        ```py
771        a = Iter([1, 2, 3, 4])
772        sum = a.fold(0, lambda acc, elem: acc + elem)
773        assert sum == 10
774        ```
775        """
776        accum = init
777        while True:
778            try:
779                x = self.__next__()
780                accum = f(accum, x)
781            except StopIteration:
782                break
783
784        return accum

Folds every element into an accumulator by applying an operation, returning the final result.

fold() takes two arguments: an initial value, and a closure with two arguments: an ‘accumulator’, and an element. The closure returns the value that the accumulator should have for the next iteration.

The initial value is the value the accumulator will have on the first call.

After applying this closure to every element of the iterator, fold() returns the accumulator.

This operation is sometimes called ‘reduce’ or ‘inject’.

Example
a = Iter([1, 2, 3, 4])
sum = a.fold(0, lambda acc, elem: acc + elem)
assert sum == 10
def advance_by(self, n: int) -> '_result.Result[None, int]': 
786    def advance_by(self, n: int) -> _result.Result[None, int]:
787        """Advances the iterator by `n` elements.
788
789        Returns `Result[None, int]`, where `Ok(None)` means the iterator
790        advanced successfully, and `Err(int)` if `None` encountered, where `int`
791        represents the remaining number of steps that could not be advanced because the iterator ran out.
792
793        Example
794        -------
795        ```py
796        it = into_iter([1, 2, 3, 4])
797        assert it.advance_by(2).is_ok()
798        assert it.next() == Some(3)
799        assert it.advance_by(0).is_ok()
800        assert it.advance_by(100) == Err(99)
801        ```
802        """
803        for i in range(n):
804            try:
805                self.__next__()
806            except StopIteration:
807                return _result.Err(n - i)
808
809        return _result.Ok(None)

Advances the iterator by n elements.

Returns Result[None, int], where Ok(None) means the iterator advanced successfully, and Err(int) if None encountered, where int represents the remaining number of steps that could not be advanced because the iterator ran out.

Example

async def async_for_each( self, func: Callable[[~Item], Coroutine[typing.Any, typing.Any, ~OtherItem]]) -> '_result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], futures.JoinError]': 
870    async def async_for_each(
871        self,
872        func: collections.Callable[
873            [Item], collections.Coroutine[typing.Any, typing.Any, OtherItem]
874        ],
875    ) -> _result.Result[collections.Sequence[OtherItem], futures.JoinError]:
876        """Calls the async function on each item in the iterator *concurrently*.
877
878        Concurrently meaning that the next item will not wait for other items
879        to finish to execute, each item gets called in a separate task.
880
881        After all the tasks finish, a `Result[list[T], JoinError]` will be returned,
882        which will need to be handled by the caller.
883
884        Example
885        -------
886        ```py
887        async def create_user(username: str) -> None:
888            await aiohttp.request("POST", f'.../{username}')
889
890        async def main():
891            users = sain.into_iter(["Danny", "Flower"])
892            match await users.async_for_each(lambda username: create_user(username)):
893                case Ok(result):
894                    # all good
895                case Err(why):
896                    print(f"couldn't gather all futures, err={why}")
897        ```
898
899        Parameters
900        ----------
901        func: `collections.Callable[[Item], Coroutine[None, Any, Any]]`
902            The async function to call on each item in the iterator.
903        """
904        return await futures.join(*(func(item) for item in self))

Calls the async function on each item in the iterator concurrently.

Concurrently meaning that the next item will not wait for other items to finish to execute, each item gets called in a separate task.

After all the tasks finish, a Result[list[T], JoinError] will be returned, which will need to be handled by the caller.

Example
async def create_user(username: str) -> None:
    await aiohttp.request("POST", f'.../{username}')

async def main():
    users = sain.into_iter(["Danny", "Flower"])
    match await users.async_for_each(lambda username: create_user(username)):
        case Ok(result):
            # all good
        case Err(why):
            print(f"couldn't gather all futures, err={why}")

555@rustc_diagnostic_item("deprecated")
556def deprecated(
557    *,
558    obj: collections.Callable[P, U] | None = None,
559    since: typing.Literal["CURRENT_VERSION"] | LiteralString | None = None,
560    removed_in: LiteralString | None = None,

562    hint: LiteralString | None = None,

564    collections.Callable[P, U]
565    | collections.Callable[
566        [collections.Callable[P, U]],
567        collections.Callable[P, U],
568    ]
569):
570    """A decorator that marks a function as deprecated.
571
572    An attempt to call the object that's marked will cause a runtime warn.
573
574    Example
575    -------
576    ```py
577    from sain import deprecated
578
579    @deprecated(
580        since = "1.0.0",
581        removed_in ="3.0.0",
582        use_instead = "UserImpl()",
583        hint = "Hint for ux."
584    )
585    class User:
586        # calling the decorator is not necessary.
587        @deprecated
588        def username(self) -> str:
589            ...
590
591    user = User() # This will cause a warning at runtime.
592
593    ```
594
595    Parameters
596    ----------
597    since : `str`
598        The version that the function was deprecated. the `CURRENT_VERSION` is used internally only.
599    removed_in : `str | None`
600        If provided, It will log when will the object will be removed in.
601    use_instead : `str | None`
602        If provided, This should be the alternative object name that should be used instead.
603    hint: `str`
604        An optional hint for the user.
605    """
606
607    def _create_message(
608        f: typing.Any,
609    ) -> str:
610        msg = f"{_obj_type(f)} `{f.__module__}.{f.__name__}` is deprecated."
611
612        if since is not None:
613            if since == "CURRENT_VERSION":
614                from ._misc import __version__
615
616                msg += " since " + __version__
617            else:
618                msg += " since " + since
619
620        if removed_in:
621            msg += f" Scheduled for removal in `{removed_in}`."
622
623        if use_instead is not None:
624            msg += f" Use `{use_instead}` instead."
625
626        if hint:
627            msg += f" Hint: {hint}"
628        return msg
629
630    def decorator(func: collections.Callable[P, U]) -> collections.Callable[P, U]:
631        message = _create_message(func)
632
633        @functools.wraps(func)
634        def wrapper(*args: P.args, **kwargs: P.kwargs) -> U:
635            _warn(message, warn_ty=DeprecationWarning)
636            return func(*args, **kwargs)
637
638        # idk why pyright doesn't know the type of wrapper.
639        m = f"\n# Warning ⚠️\n{message}."
640        if wrapper.__doc__:
641            # append this message to an existing document.
642            wrapper.__doc__ = inspect.cleandoc(wrapper.__doc__) + f"{m}"
643        else:
644            wrapper.__doc__ = m
645
646        return wrapper
647
648    # marked only.
649    if obj is not None:
650        return decorator(obj)
651
652    return decorator

@rustc_diagnostic_item('assert_ne')
def assert_ne(left: +T, right: +T) -> None: 
404@rustc_diagnostic_item("assert_ne")
405def assert_ne(left: T, right: T) -> None:
406    """Asserts that two expressions are not equal to each other.
407
408    This exactly as `assert left == right`, but includes a useful message in case of failure.
409
410    Example
411    -------
412    ```py
413    from sain.macros import assert_ne
414    a = 3
415    b = 2 + 2
416    assert_ne(a, b)
417    ```
418    """
419    assert (
420        left != right
421    ), f'assertion `left != right` failed\nleft: "{left!r}"\nright: "{right!r}"'
